lcInstruction.p: As part of giving a reader an instruction, there may be more than one option for the reader. For example, when using an auto stereo system, the user has the choice of which mode to use (AM, FM, CD, line-in, and so on).

To present this information, and to give it a semantically appropriate label, you can use the <choices> or <choicetable> elements. Both present choices: use <choices> when the choices only require a brief description; use <choicetable> when you need to provide specific keywords, along with an extended description.
The elements contained in the <choicetable> element include:

stentry.p: The container element for the header row of a <choicetable> element. The <chhead> element contains the <choptionhd> and <chdeschd> elements and is optional. There can only be one <chhead> element in a <choicetable> element.

The container element for the option cell in the header row of a element. The element contains the option text, which should be wrapped in a

element according to best practice.

The container element for the description cell in the header row of a element. The element contains the description text, which should be wrapped in a

element according to best practice.
The container element for a row in a <choicetable> element. The <chrow> element contains the <choption> and <chdesc> elements. There can be one or more <chrow> elements in a <choicetable> element.

The container element for the option cell in a row of a element. The element contains the option text, which should be wrapped in a

element according to best practice.

The container element for the description cell in a row of a element. The element contains the description text, which should be wrapped in a

element according to best practice.
